title: About
text: Hello! I’m Tyler Brown, a Statistics & Data Analytics major at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Welcome to my sports blog! I’m passionate about data analysis across all sports, with a particular focus on the NFL. Through this blog, I aim to share my insights and explore the fascinating ways data can deepen our understanding of sports.

title: Does Geno Smith deserve to be considered a top tier quarterback?
text:
The comeback of Geno Smith has been an interesting story in the NFL the last couple of years. Geno claims he “ain’t write back though” to all the haters that had already written him off from the start of 2023. His 2023 season was a great sight to see if you’re a Seahawks fan like myself. However this begs the question, is Geno continuing this success into 2024? To go even further, does he deserve to be considered a top tier quarterback?
To try and answer this question, let’s look at some 2024 passing data.
First, let’s look at simply passing yards. Who is getting the most passing yards through Week 12 of the 2024 season?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(rvest)
library(waffle)
NFL2024PassingURL1 <- "https://www.nfl.com/stats/player-stats/"
NFL2024PassingURL2 <- "https://www.nfl.com/stats/player-stats/category/passing/2024/REG/all/passingyards/DESC?aftercursor=AAAAGQAAABlAm4AAAAAAADFleUp6WldGeVkyaEJablJsY2lJNld5SXhOell3SWl3aU16SXdNRFUwTkRFdE5EYzJNaTB3TXpRMExUTmhORFl0TWpZNVpqVmxOV1U0TlRSbElpd2lNakF5TkNKZGZRPT0="

NFL2024Passing1 <- NFL2024PassingURL1 |>
  read_html() |>
  html_nodes(xpath = '//*[@id="main-content"]/section[3]') |>
  html_table()

NFL2024Passing2 <- NFL2024PassingURL2 |>
  read_html() |>
  html_nodes(xpath = '//*[@id="main-content"]/section[3]') |>
  html_table()

NFL2024Passing <- bind_rows(NFL2024Passing1, NFL2024Passing2)

Top20NFL2024Passing <- NFL2024Passing |>
  top_n(20, `Pass Yds`)

Geno <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Geno Smith")

Lamar <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

Josh <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Josh Allen")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=Top20NFL2024Passing, aes(x=reorder(Player, `Pass Yds`), weight=`Pass Yds`), fill="lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=Geno, aes(x=reorder(Player, `Pass Yds`), weight=`Pass Yds`), fill="#69B140") +
  geom_bar(data=Lamar, aes(x=reorder(Player, `Pass Yds`), weight=`Pass Yds`), fill="#241773") +
  geom_bar(data=Josh, aes(x=reorder(Player, `Pass Yds`), weight=`Pass Yds`), fill="#D50032") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Geno Smith soars to the top of the NFL in passing yards",
    subtitle = "The Seattle QB is behind only one of the MVP front runners",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Passing Yards",
    caption = "By: Tyler Brown | Source: nfl.com"
  ) +
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  )









Wow! Geno is above tons of big names like Patrick Mahomes, Joe Burrow, and Josh Allen. He sits only 18 yards behind one of the MVP front runners in Lamar Jackson.
However, there is something else that might be playing a role here. Seattle has one of the most pass first offenses in the league. That may contribute to why Geno gets so many yards. Because of that, let’s look at something maybe more indicative of QB ability regardless of the type of offense, touchdown vs interception ratio. We’ll compare Geno to the two MVP front runners, Lamar Jackson and Josh Allen


Code
GenoTDInt <- c("Touchdowns" = 12, "Interceptions" = 12, 4)
LamarTDInt <- c("Touchdowns" = 25, "Interceptions" = 3)
JoshTDInt <- c("Touchdowns" = 18, "Interceptions" = 5, 5)

iron(
  waffle(
    GenoTDInt,
    rows = 3,
    colors = c("#69B140", "#002244","white")
  ) +
    labs(
      title = "Geno throwing the ball away instead of scoring TDs",
      subtitle = "Smith is scoring less and throwing more interceptions than Jackson and Allen "
    ) +
    theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
      axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
      axis.title.y = element_blank(),
      plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
    ),
  waffle(
    LamarTDInt,
    rows = 3,
    colors = c("#241773", "#FCB514")
  ),
  waffle(
    JoshTDInt,
    rows = 3,
    colors = c("#00338D", "#C60C30","white")
    ) +
    labs(
      x = "1 square = 1 touchdown or interception",
      caption = "By: Tyler Brown | Source: nfl.com"
    )
)









Ouch. Not looking good for Geno here. He has an even touchdown to interception ratio. That is not very good. Lamar Jackson and Josh Allen have him beat here by a lot.
Let’s look at one more thing. How effective is Geno at getting the ball far downfield, but also connecting with his receivers when doing so?


Code
Geno <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Geno Smith")

Lamar <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

Josh <- NFL2024Passing |>
  filter(Player == "Josh Allen")

AvgYPA <- mean(NFL2024Passing$`Yds/Att`)
AvgCmpPCT <- mean(NFL2024Passing$`Cmp %`)

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = NFL2024Passing, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`), color = "grey") +
  geom_point(data = Geno, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`), color = "#69B140") +
  geom_point(data = Lamar, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`), color = "#241773") +
  geom_point(data = Josh, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`), color = "#C60C30") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 6.992, color = "black",size = 1) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 64.524, color = "black",size = 1) +
  geom_text(aes(x = 6.992, y = max(NFL2024Passing$`Cmp %`) + 0.5, label = "Average Yards Per Attempt"),
            color = "black", vjust = 0, hjust = 0.55) +
  geom_text(aes(x = max(NFL2024Passing$`Yds/Att`) - 0.5, y = 64.524, label = "Average Completion Percentage"),
            color = "black",vjust = 1.1, hjust = 0.6) +
  geom_text(data = Geno, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`, label = "Geno Smith"),
            color = "#69B140", vjust = -1, hjust = 0.5, size = 3.5) +
  geom_text(data = Lamar, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`, label = "Lamar Jackson"),
            color = "#241773", vjust = -1, hjust = 0.5, size = 3.5) +
  geom_text(data = Josh, aes(x = `Yds/Att`, y = `Cmp %`, label = "Josh Allen"),
            color = "#C60C30", vjust = -1, hjust = 0.5, size = 3.5) +
  geom_text(aes(x = 8.9, y = 71, label = "Throwing Long And Connecting"), 
            color = "grey", size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 8.7, y = 55, label = "Throwing Long And Not Connecting"), 
            color = "grey", size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 5.7, y = 55, label = "Not Throwing Long And Not Connecting"), 
            color = "grey", size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 5.5, y = 71, label = "Not Throwing Long But Connecting"), 
            color = "grey", size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  theme_minimal() +
   labs(
    title = "Geno launching it downfield and connecting",
    subtitle = "Smith is able to throw it deep and complete passes at a high percentage",
    x = "Yards Per Attempt",
    y = "Completion Percentage",
    caption = "By: Tyler Brown | Source: nfl.com"
  ) +
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  )









Hey, what do you know. He’s pretty good in this category, up in that first quadrant of guys who are able to throw it long and connect with receivers at a high rate. He’s got a better completion percentage than both Jackson and Allen.
So what’s the conclusion? It seems that Geno is a pretty good NFL QB. He gets lots of passing yards (even for being in a pass first offense), and has the high completion percentage while throwing it deep to boot. However, he seems to struggle with giving the ball to the other team too much, and with making it to the end zone. It’ll be interesting to see if he can clean up the turnovers and throw some more touchdowns. If he can, he might just earn a spot among the NFL’s top-tier quarterbacks.
